Graduate enrollment increasing
By BOB BUCHANAN
With total enrollment up
roughly 200, registration figures
for the 1974-75 academic year at
the Hopkins Evening College
reflect a trend towards increased
enrollment in the College's
graduate program.
Dean of the Evening College,
Roman J. Verhaalen, asserted
that , "Last year, out of
approximately 5,000 students,
we had 2800 undergraduate
students and 2300 graduate
students. This year out of 5200
students registered in the Evening
College we have 2300
undergraduates and 2900
graduate students. The coin has
flipped."
These figures reflect a trend
towards a larger graduate student
enrollment in the Evening
College, first discernible in the
early 1970's.
Verhaalen commented, "By
the early 1970's we had almost as
many graduate degrees awarded
as bachelor degrees. Now we're

to the point where more
[students] graduate with
graduate degrees than
undergraduate degrees."
This propensity has increased.
In 1974, out of the 774 diplomas
granted by the Evening College.
550 were to persons who had
completed graduate studies.
The high cost of tuition at the
Evening College was cited as one
possible reason by Verhaalen for
the decline in figures in
undergraduate enrollment.
"It costs more at Hopkins to
meet the necessary requirements
for the BA degree than from one
of the local state community
colleges," said Verhaalen.
At present, tuition at the
Evening College is $45 per credit
hour with a $20 application fee.
At nearby Anne Arundel
Community College, one of the
state community colleges to
which Verhaalen referred, tuition
charges were $12 per credit hour
for the 1973-74 academic year
with a $10 application fee.

Verhaalen cited another
possible reason for the trend.
"The Hopkins' name is more
important on the graduate level
than the undergraduate level."
Verhaalen maintained that
these relatively high charges for
students were necessary to meet
the costs incurred by the
operation of the Evening College.
Commenting on the budget of
the Evening College, he asserted,
"If you take all the direct and
indirect costs involved, we
operate on a balanced budget

enrollment in the College's
graduate program.
Dean of the Evening College,
Roman J. Verhaalen, asserted
that , "Last year, out of
approximately 5,000 students,
we had 2800 undergraduate
students and 2300 graduate
students. This year out of 5200
students registered in the Evening
College we have 2300
undergraduates and 2900
graduate students. The coin has
flipped."

enrollment in the Evening

the early 1970's we had almost as
many graduate degrees awarded

graduate degrees than
undergraduate degrees."

granted by the Evening College.
550 were to persons who had
completed graduate studies.

Evening College was cited as one
possible reason by Verhaalen for
the decline in figures in
undergraduate enrollment.
"It costs more at Hopkins to
meet the necessary requirements
for the BA degree than from one
of the local state community
colleges," said Verhaalen.

Evening College is $45 per credit
hour with a $20 application fee.

Community College, one of the
state community colleges to

charges were $12 per credit hour

possible reason for the trend.
"The Hopkins' name is more
important on the graduate level

these relatively high charges for

operation of the Evening College.

operate on a balanced budget

"indirect costs."
The Johns Hopkins University

education, according to
Verhaalen. "It was tho first
institution of higher learning
which allowed students to
matriculate for full degree
programs."
